This is a frame that accepts Hubsan X4 micro quadcopter guts. Motor openings may need to be manually enlarged based on printer settings.
All models should be complete solids now. Versions are in order of apperence above. These frames are designed to fit 7mm motors, however with a little heat and the right tools 8mm can fit. V3: I took everything i did on the V2.1 frame but did it right this time. Box now fits the Flight control board/ receiver. Added bigger gusseting to the motor mounts after breaking all my V2.1 frames in the same spot. Slimmed down bracing inside the arms and removed excess material to hopefully make this thing within 5 grams of original frame weight but indestructible. V2.1 Even more gusseting, more speed holes, better "engineering". The box in which the receiver board is supposed to mount into was modeled too small! The board will not fit into the box as it was designed to do. This frame was 12grams printed .2mm, 4shells 0%infill PLA V2. Redesign with same idea in mind, lighter yet. defiantly have to play with printer settings to make this one strong. * This design is flawed, see above!** V1.1 Slimmed down the arms a bit and added gussets. little lighter. V1. Super strong but super heavy.

First test (printed and "working") of my hypocycloid gearbox generator (scad file at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:481167). Pics will follow when I get my camera back! This version needs improvements to avoid jerky output motion. Perhaps changing parameters in scad file (peg diameter, etc). Still interesting test that proved it worked! Note - the linked-to scad file isn't exactly neat and tidy! Sorry!! (still learning)

requires:
2x 10 mm ID / 15 mm OD bearings. 4 mm high
2x 6 mm ID / 19 mm OD bearings. 6 mm high.
1x ~70 mm M6 threaded shaft.
4x 30 mm M3 cap screws.
4 (to 6)x 10-15 mm M3 cap screws and nuts.
6x M6 nuts
4x self tapping screws. <=10 mm long, ~2.5 mm dia. Construction:
Print "Complete.stl" (PLA, no raft or support, 0.4 mm nozzle / 0.2 mm layers, 12-20% infill, 2-3 shells (skienforge47)).
OR: Print from individual files as you wish to experiment. If using ABS, you will need to add 'tabs' to the corners of the larger parts to avoid warping. Output shaft assembly:
Attach the output annulus (OutputAnnulus.stl) to the output shaft with 2 M6 nuts (one above, one below). Use threadlocker if you want it permanent! Then capture the two 6 mm bearings between 4 more nuts (nut, bearing, nut, nut, bearing, nut), and line up bearings to fit slots in the upper housing (UpperHousing.stl) before tightening bearings in place. Now, screw together the two upper housings with the shaft in place using the 10-15 mm M3 screws and nuts. Sun assembly:
Insert a 10 / 15 mm bearing into the lower sun section (SunBottom.stl). Insert the cam on top of this (cam.stl), place another 10 / 15 mm bearing on the top of the cam, and push the upper sun section into place (SunTop.stl). Screw together (or glue if you wish) with four self-tapping screws (10 mm long max, ~2.5 mm thread). Place the motor mount (MotorPlate.stl) onto the motor, and push the sun assembly onto the motor SCREW SIDE DOWN (I got top / bottom mixed up in the code!). Then place the central housing (LowerHousing.stl) on top of the motor mount. Finally, add the output shaft assembly, and screw in place with 30 mm M3 screws. Once constructed, I found this gearbox a little sticky until I wore it in a bit with the help of some chrome polish paste mixed with grease. I cleaned out the polish after I decided it was probably as smooth as it was getting.

comments.text:
I'm thinking of printing this excellent looking piece. Can you tell me if it was generated by your previously released scad or was some other work done in it. If there are later versions I'd like to explore that first.
I've got access to a Projet 1500 for printing in plastic resin, and I want to make sure the tolerances will be okay. I also was wondering if a bolt for the output shaft might be practical. Although getting a sufficiently long bolt with threads to the head might be a problem.
comments.author: VA3AE

comments.text: Been a while since I looked at the SCAD file! I should also add that the "Clearence" parameter is used as a global means to set the excess material to compensate for - on my FDM printer with a 0.4 mm nozzle, I get approximately 0.2 mm too much material when printing. Hence, Clearence is set to 0.2. For a resin printer (photo-activated resin using a laser I assume) your Clearence may work at a lower value. Never tried a resin printer though! Clearence will also impact on backlash in the gearbox, and at too high a value may cause jamming.
comments.author: VA3AE

comments.text: Oh - and if you can't get a bolt with threads close enough to the head, you can always use a die to cut threads further down.
comments.author: VA3AE

comments.text:
V1.31 of the scad hypocycloid generator was used for this (back in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:481167/#files) I've not had much chance to do more work with it yet. I use a length of M6 threaded rod for the output, but a long enough bolt should work fine. Can't remember if I said in the description, but I had to 'wear it in' a fair bit using Autosol chrome polish mixed with grease. You may find that your printer produces far better results :) The default $fn value in the file will likely be insufficient - change it to 50 or higher before you generate parts for printing. Also, the section of the file that says:
DrawCam = 1, //Draw the cam if equal to 1
DrawSunTop = 1, //Draw the hypocycloid sun if equal to 1
DrawSunBottom = 1, //Draw the hypocycloid sun if equal to 1
DrawStaticAnnulus = 1, //Draw the static annulus if equal to 1
DrawOutputAnnulus = 1, //Draw the output (moving) annulus if equal to 1
DrawMotorPlate = 1,
DrawBearings = 1, //Draw the dummy bearings if equal to 1
DrawHousing = 1,
DrawHousing1 = 1,
is used to select the individual sections of the model for printing (they're all set to 1 in the above, but I think the released file has only one of them set active). If you have experience of OpenSCAD though, then I suspect you can deal with that :D

title: Printrbot Simple 1405 "TRI ROD MOD" with or without XL tower upgrade (first 1405 XL tower)

description.text: This mod adds a third linear rod in both the Y and Z axes. The third rod greatly reduces the amount of twisting that can occur, especially with an extended Y mod installed. This mod is based off of Jon Lawrence's 300mm no sag mod. It also includes modifications to a couple of other's works which I will list in the remixed from area. UPDATE (12/13/2014): After printing out the model for the "TRI_ROD_MOD_TOP1_XL", I found out it didn't fit because the models for the XL wood parts were not correct. I have measured my actual wooden XL parts and have redesigned this part to now fit correctly. I also beefed it up a bit. UPDATE(2/13/2015): I uploaded a new step file with just the parts for the non XL version. I also have separate step files for the 2 biggest parts. I verified that these can be imported with FreeCad. P.S. I will try and work out a basic hardware list sometime soon. P.P.S. I am also working on another version of this mod that will be integrated into the "JONbot". Nothing from this version will be compatible. The XL tower parts will also be integrated and are printed, no wood parts will be used at all. UPDATE (FEB/15/2015): I have modified all of the big parts to be printable on a 100 x 100 print area. There is a new STEP file with all of the 100x100 printable parts as well as STL files of each. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QpEauZWP_l4

I'l eventually add something here, just wanted to get the files up in case anyone wants to experiment.  If anyone wants to mod any of this I have included a step file (.stp) that has all parts including models of the wooden parts including the first 1405 XL tower along with models of a beefed up "aluminum" extruder and Ubis hotend.  I also have a parametric file (.x_t)  with the same models.

comments.text: You can go more than 300 in the X but I wouldn't try and go more than 300 in the Y.  Even with 3 rods that is very far to be suspended out. They have a 300x300 silicone heat bead on amazon I picked up but haven't installed it yet. The mod I am currently working on will not be compatible with any other parts, custom or stock.  It is going to be a fully printed bot based on the printed Jonbot but with the tri-rod mod built in, like the one orangefurball made posted below. I am tweaking the rod spacing so no older parts will work with the new one. The XL tower will also be printed.  The X bearings will be farther apart for more stability for wider tables and there is also an optional part that will bring the front bearings out to the front of a 300mm bed. If you use the optional front part you could also have the bed riding on 3 rods and 6 bearings, you would just have to adjust the bearings to be very close to perfectly aligned with each other so the table won't bind in the X.  The optional front part will also allow you to drive your X with another stepper which would run reverse to the first one and be linked by a driveshaft.  I'm nearly finished designing the part but I'm waiting on some parts before I can test print anything.  My Ubis failed(nichrome wire broke) so I am waiting on a new hot end.

title: Twisted Napkin Ring
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Head in a twist about how to make your table stand out? Print a few of these napkin rings and that should do the trick. But don't be boring. Invest in a few extra spools of different colored filament so that every setting ends up with something different to say. Not for you? Have a conversation with the Spiral collection or Crown Napkin Ring designs to see if they speak to you. An Inventor Studios Tinkercad tutorial walks first semester 3D modeling students through this design. Follow the entire collection to refine your modeling skills.

The stresses that can build up across this design from tip to tail can cause the piece to snap rather easily. So 3 or even 4 shells are recommended. They can be printed either "laying down" or "standing up", but enable supports either way. They look great in both ABS and PLA.

comments.text: The question's been raised about how printable this design is. So I've added 2 Makes of the design with unadorned photos that show both the "money" and bottom perspectives. One was printed standing up, the other laying down. One was sliced with Makerbot Desktop 3.4, the other with Simplify3D. Both were printed in ABS on a FlashForge Creator X. I have a PLA print running on a Makerbot Replicator 2 that I'll post as another Make once it's done.
comments.author: neobobkrause

comments.author: Chasedevries

comments.text: An astute observation. Yes, printing this design requires a bit more attention than do the other napkin rings I've released. But it's definitely doable. Despite its shortcomings, my slicer of choice is the proprietary product Simplify3d. It is able to print this design well without the need to add any manual supports. But I also am getting good results using the latest Makerbot Desktop, version  3.4, when the twist is standing up. I'm an ABS guy myself. But my experience tells me that PLA will be even easier, so long as the fan is blowing right below the extruder nozzle.

title: Slotted waveguide for TP-link WR703N
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a slotted waveguide antenna for the tp-link WR703N wifi travel router. It fits over the box, so no modifications to the router are needed. It changes the radiation pattern to a pie-segment shape: horizontally it is about 120degrees wide, vertically it is much narrower.
The dimensions are limited by the lasercutter I used, an antenna with more slots would give a better gain.
I have not tested this antenna yet...

Cut out the drawings from 3mm plywood, I used birch ply, but any wood that cuts good on the laser is fine, 1/8" should work as well.
Assemble the box without the front panel. I had to use an extra offset (in the drawing) to compensate for the laser kerf thickness. It was designed to be a tight press fit, but If you wish to use glue that is fine too (probably better if you wish to use it outdoors).
With the backside assembled, spray glue on the inside. Cover the inside with aluminium foil, making sure not to puncture the foil in the corners. Fold the foil over the side and cut it off any excess.
Cover the front panel backside with foil too, take care to cut away the foil from the slots as those are very important for the function of the antenna.
Next glue or tape the tp-link box on its spot at the bottom. Its edge should just align with the edge of the bottom panel.
Lastly , put the front panel in to close the box. The more electrical contact you have with the back, the better. sorry, the TV interface seems to be broken again. I cannot upload a flickr image:
here is one: http://www.flickr.com/photos/protospace/8527427267/in/photostream
edit: no, it is the design that is broken: ther eis a textbox, but with it being white on white, is is functionally unfindable. -1 for vocking design. here is the link that I used to calculate dimensions: http://www.protospace.nl/fabmoments/wr703n-slotted-waveguide here is the thing on our site, in dutch, with some more pictures: http://www.protospace.nl/fabmoments/wr703n-slotted-waveguide

comments.text:
You did not read the instructions, did you?
The instructions telly you to line the inside with aluminium foil and cut out the slots. You cannot cut metal with a common 35Watt CO2 lasercutter, hence the plywood that is covered with alu foil later.

I am going to say that I am just basing my work on that of others - these are just what I did with the existing information and models. I followed this tutorial for my entire assembly, adapting where it made sense - http://www.instructables.com/id/Polargraph-Drawing-Machine/ Also this site for more information and up to date software http://www.polargraph.co.uk/ I am using two nema 17 motors from Adafruit. The motors are run with an arduino Uno and adafruit v1 motorshield (I had this just laying around, it turns out that it works perfect with the 'firmware' for the bot). I have a 12v 1.5a power supply running the motor shield and I have isolated (through removal of the jumper on the board) it from the Uno which is getting power and information from my PC. Two 6' 3.5mm ball chains are being used as both gears and pulleys for the system - these work great for this project. I flashed the 'firmware' from this github https://github.com/euphy/polargraphcontroller/releases/latest The firmware is a set of Uno sketches which you will need to adjust for whatever motor shield you are using - it appears V2 is more problematic than V1, but that is just from a few posts I have read. V1 is working fine for me. The software is located here https://github.com/euphy/polargraphcontroller/releases/tag/1.10.6a Read the wiki for more info on the software release - https://github.com/euphy/polargraph It was pretty intuitive after a little bit of use. Restart quite a bit. Make sure you follow the instructions on calibrating your machine on the indestructables, it corrected many issues my machine had out of the gate.

I would disable my extruder and turn on the laser and it will follow the gcode same as if it had a hot end. remixed_from.author: tosjduenfs
remixed_from.title: Mini Flame Wheel Style Quadcopter frame.

description.text:
Update 23.01.2015:
Stronger camera mount. Less chance of the tabs breaking. Less support needed.

This is a bottom plate for the fantastic Mini Flamewheel Quadcopter.
The mobius camera mount slides into the gap on the plate and is held into place with two cable ties and two small plastic nubs. Those are kind of easy to break, but the best I could do without making the bottom plate even thicker.
When the camera is used, the battery is placed towards the back for balancing. When the camera is not used, the entire mobius mount can be removed, so the battery can be slid forwards. This way, there's no need to fly heavily unbalanced or swap the bottom plate. Stick a strip of velcro on the bottom of the plate to keep the battery in place.
The camera is mounted upside-down, so change the 180° option in the mobius settings.
Some sanding is likely required on the cable tie "wings" on the mount, unless your printer is very good at printing floating overhangs. Support is needed of course.
Also sand the small bumps at the front that hold the mobius at an angle, if you find it tough to get the camera out.
Print at 30% infill in ABS, preferably, as PLA is rather stiff.

title: 3mm Infill 3D Bowden Direct Drive Extruder v2

description.text:
Same extruder as the "Infill 3D Bowden Direct Drive Extruder v2" but in 3mm also I added some attachment holes and minor improvements.
First version in 3mm, please let me know how it works, future updates will be here... https://infill3d.com/28-extruders

This extruder is not composed of many printed parts only 2 if you are going to use direct mount or 4 if you are going to use the dove tail bracket.
The extruder is made to be used with a MK8 drive gear, if you put a bigger drive gear might not fit keep that in mind.
I am not adding the mounting screws to the part list since people are going to use different length screws for their machines but note that you are going to use M3 socket screws for mounting the extruder. If you use the direct mount, the holes are in the extruder body they are 13.5mm center to center.
Pneumatic fittings, I set it up to use 2 to give the ability to route PTFE tube to the filament reel however it will work without the fitting.
The screw that holds the idler is there to hold the idler only not to hold the extruder against the motor just tighten it enough so the idler is in place correctly.
Use caution when threading the fittings into the extruder is easy to strip or crack the body.
Parts you are going to need... 1x MK8 Drive gear
1x 603ZZ
2x Pneumatic fitting 1/8 to 6mm (Or what fits your Bowden tube)
2x 1/4" x 1/2" x .035" (6.350 x 12.7 x .889mm) Utility comp springs (Extruder to idler)
2x M3 Washers (Springs)
3x M3 Nuts (Spring screws, idler)
3x M3X25 Socket head screws (Extruder to motor)
2x M3X30 Socket head screws (Extruder to idler springs)
1x M3X16 Socket screw (Idler)

Hi Dan, you are right it can be done however it would add to it's size and change it's looks also the whole geometry of the top where the filament travels to the drive gear would have to change to make space for the larger diameter of the 608 maybe shortening the support of the filament to the drive gear, that feature is important since I want to try using it with soft filaments like ninja flex that usually can't be used in Bowden setups hence the supports almost all the way to the drive gear; to add to it I know a lot of folks out there do not care about looks only function but both are important to me a 608 is going to add too much bulk.

that is $0.585 per bearing, if you are like me I buy a bunch and keep them for my future projects and even if you are not they are so cheap you can use one put the rest in a drawer and forget about them for the next time you need them, $0.585 will save you time and headaches.

title: Picture frame 4 in x 6 in landscape

description.text: This is a 6" wide x 4" tall (102mm x 153mm) picture frame. It has a built in stand, and a slide-in back plate, to keep the picture in.

I used 10% infill and 0.27 mm layer height and it took about 1 hour for each part (accelerated). I use 230F nozzle and 110F bed temperature. Careful, the frame back can stick to the kapton tape. I tried with a bridge but it was almost impossible to remove.
The frame back is 0.5mm smaller than the front, so it slides in pretty good.
I plan to modify it slightly so the back has a ridge to slide down all the way. Right now, the frame back is supported on the front at the top and bottom. (Also, I'll take a better picture of the frame.)

This is a ducted fan mount for a Makerbot/Cupcake with MK5 Extruder. It seems to successfully stop small objects from turning into molten blobs.
The whole thing clips into the extruder mount. It uses an old fan from the junk box, I think it was from a graphics card or similar.
Mostly cools the current top layer of the printing object without pushing the platform heater into desperation. I'm running the fan through a 200 Ohm potentiometer, to control the airflow.
The air flow is down and towards the nozzle, roughly 45 degrees. The air follows the extruder hot end and reaches about 60 degrees by the time it hits the object.

The thing prints without support.
The ducts have a designed central support that helps with the bridging for the top layers.
The outlet support pillars can be cut away or left standing. Mine broke off while cleaning the ducts.
The fan is 'mounted' with 3 drops of superglue.

comments.text: Absolutely brilliant! I had been trying to deal with the cooling issue for overhangs and tall, narrow things through a combination of Skeinforge Cool (which really slows down the prints and doesn't do much for overhangs) and lowering the extruder temperature (which causes delamination problems). A couple of quick test prints showed that I could up the extruder temp to 230C and still print tall features 1 x 5mm with no sagging or delamination.

title: Rahwah Wilderness west branch trail topographical map

description.text:
This is of the Rahwah Wilderness west branch trail in Colorado Rockies. I went on a 4 day backpacking trip this past summer on the West branch loop. The landscape was breathtaking, after receiving my Printer I have been waiting for a way to print the landscape. I hope someone finds this stl useful. The stl prints great, no holes in the model. I will upload a picture of mine when I get a chance. Dont forget to print with a Z offset of -105mm to remove the huge boxed bottom. Source for the topographical stl data:
http://146.148.78.19/ Used this web based stl repair tool:
https://netfabb.azurewebsites.net/ Here is some information about the trail:
http://www.trimbleoutdoors.com/ViewTrip/514812
http://www.oriconline.org/what_to_do/trails_and_trips/backpacking_trips/cc-west_branch_loop.pdf

I printed the model at .1mm layer height for great detail and chose 15% infill. You can probably get away with less infill, maybe 10%.  
I printed with a Z offset of -105mm to remove the huge boxed bottom.

description.text: Did some reading about Chaos theory and Attractors and I wanted to put my hands on the shapes rather than looking at them in the computer. This is a model of a Lorenz Attractor (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lorenz_system) with b= 8/3, ?= 10, r= 28. The model was plotted in Mathematica and the path was "tubified" in order to fill in gaps and make it printable. The model is 62mm wide, 44mm tall, and 26mm deep. The base is 25.4mm x 25.4mm. The pictures show the model printed at 200% scale. If you like this I am also working on a model of a Rossler Attractor. I'm having difficulty making the stl perfectly manifold so if you have any tips please let me know.

description.text:
Hi All!
This is my car phone bracket that slots into the CD player.
It's fully adjustable and has a hole in the bottom for a micro usb charger. It's non intrusive and keeps your Dashboard and windscreen free of clutter and obstruction. It should be compatible with most smartphones as long as the phone is no wider than 85mm so some phablets may not fit, also the brackets are 13mm deep so should be able to hold most phones in bumper cases etc. Here is the BOM
2 x M3x8mm hex socket screws and 2 x M3 washers (to secure side brackets)
2 x M3x6mm hex socket screws(to guide side brackets)
2 x M3 nuts (not Nylock) to secure side brackets You need to print 2 of the M3 caps and glue them onto the M3 x 8mm screws using superglue.
Then assemble as shown in the picture. I printed pt1 (the bit that goes into the CD slot) with 100% infill to add rigidity. other than that 20% should be fine for the rest. Enjoy!

UPDATE 16/12/2014
I modified part 1 so it sits in the stereo more securely.

author: audioland

description.text:
A nice Xmas tree that you can print instead of buying!  
Stands around 40cm tall if you wish or you can make it only ~20cm tall. It has three sections so you can print just the top section of the tree, the top section with feet, the top and middle section or the top middle and feet to have quite a big tree.   
I also made two different types of connectors so if you have filament to burn you can print the tree with 6 sections to each level OR you can use the 4 way connector and have a simpler tree.  
I recommend printing the star is glow in the dark filament it makes it nice at night!

Print out two connectors for ever how many sides you want the tree to have. So two four side connectors or 2 six sided connectors.

This is a case with lid and wall mount for the Etherten arduino board from Freetronics. http://www.freetronics.com/collections/ethernet/products/etherten Designed using Alibre.
Sliced with Netfabb.
Printed on an Ultimaker.

All three parts are designed to print without supports as oriented in the stl files:
  • Wall mount, wall face down
  • Case, closed end down
  • Lid, outside face down
    • Etherten board slides into slots and is held in place by the lid. Lid is affixed with four 10mm M3 bolts (total overkill, just for the looks). There's space for a shield too. An extra hole has been added to the lid to run a cable out to a temperature sensor for my project. Case simply slides into the wall mount. Designed to be placed on the wall with the curved sides horizontal to allow for air flow through the slots. Board doesn't get that warm, so probably doesn't matter which way you orient it, other than lid facing down; otherwise, it would fall out of the mount. Wall mount is affixed to the wall with two countersink screws. I printed it in a translucent blue PLA; looks good with the blue LED shining through it.

author: Kimmiexbollie

description.text: I am using a box-frame type Prusa i3 printer and was looking for the best place where to mount my new Smart LCD controller. From a functional point of view, I would like to have at the top right of the i3 box frame, just above the RAMPS. But I also like to keep my printer as compact as possible, and having an LCD controller stick out makes it cumbersome to carry around and also bears the risk of damaging it by hitting it unintentionally. So the aim of this project is to construct a sturdy double hinged frame which allows to firmly hold the LCD controller in the desired operating position when using the printer, and to stow it away behind the frame when it's not needed. The project consists of the LCD frame as such and a strong double hinge mechanism. Both frame and hinge mechanism can also be used independently, i.e. if the Smart LCD Controller is to be mounted in a fixed position, the hinge is not needed, and the hinge mechanism alone could well also be useful for flexibly mounting devices other than that particular controller. The Smart LCD Controller is inserted into frame part and fastened on it by means of four M3x10 screws. The hinge mechanism can be mounted on either side onto the LCD frame. The hinge axes are M4 screws which are tightened with a spring and a Nyloc nut, as to allow rotation while maintaining enough pressure to keep the frame solidly in place. The printer-side hinge also has a locking mechanism to restrict the rotation between 0 and 90 degrees. Also grooves at 0 and 90 degrees cause the hinge to snap precisely into place at the two end positions. The provided SCAD file is fully parametrized, so that it can be easily modified to particular needs, if necessary. Separate STL files are provided for the frame and the hinge parts. Left and right side versions of the hinge are provided - use the one that fits the location of the LCD on you printer. Update 2015-01-08: I just uploaded a follow-up project on this which provides the same functionality for the 12864 Full Graphics LCD Controller. Update 2015-02-21: I just uploaded an additional smaller square version of the hinge. this might be useful for situations where only little space is available for mounting the hinge.

Print the frame part and either the left or the right mounting version of the hinge assembly - depending where and in which positions you plan to install the LCD controller. Before inserting the LCD controller into the frame, make sure that there the male pin headers above the 2004 LCD do not stick out more than is needed for the solder joints - so cut off any extra length. In order to have the reset button accessible from the outside, I inserted from the inside through the corresponding hole a nylon M5x5 screw for which I had filed down the screw head to about 0.5mm. For mounting the hinges, you'll need
  • 1 screw M4x20 (printer side hinge)
  • 1 screw M4x45 (LCD side hinge)
  • 2 M4 Nyloc nuts
  • 2 M4 washers
  • 2 small springs (same I use for the geared extruder)
    • and for mounting the LCD frame to the printer's box frame, I used 4 small 3x16mm wood screws. The LCD controller is fixated in the LCD frame by 4 M3x6 screws. I printed the plastic parts from 3mm ABS filament on my DIY Prusa i3, using a 0.4mm nozzle with 0.56mm extrusion width and 0.25 layer height. I print on a clear mirror without Kapton tape, but thoroughly cleaned with acetone first and then with double concentrated lemon juice.

title: K8200 XY 10 tooth axis pulley / sprocket | with opposing set screw nut inserts

description.text:
I noticed the original pulley on my printer wasn't drilled in the center -- creating a wobble and therefore printing problems.
I printed the pulley and when installed the wobble was less pronounced. After the 3rd iteration it was running completely true.
Note the 4mm setscrews have nuts that are inserted into the slots at the end of the pulley and they are opposing one another which mitigates distortion when they are tightened.
Number of Teeth: 10
Shaft Diameter: 5mm
Outside Diameter: 15 mm

Tout dépend de ta surface que tu veux imprimer. C'est très utile pour aider les couche à refroidir plus vite. Pour les petites surfaces ce n'est pas suffisant.
Il y a 2 points négatif à mon goût; 1 ça cache la buse, on ne vois pas ce que l'on imprime et 2 ça augmente le volume d'encombrement de la tête d'impression.
autre chose à prendre en compte qui n'est pas négligeable, ça refroidit la buse. Donc si tu es juste en puissance pour fondre un matériau qui a besoin de beaucoup de puissance, c'est pénalisant.

comments.author: Aure51800

comments.text:
Salut, il n'y a pas du tout besoin de l'option led. Je dirais même qu'on ne peux pas monter les deux en même temps. J'ai utilisé les trous d'interface de l'option led pour fixer le fan duct. Pour le branchemant j'ai fais une petite modification ; le ventilateur qui étai branché à coté de la thermistance, je l'ai déplacé pour le brancher entre le moteur extrudeur et le moteur 1 pour y mettre le ventilateur du fan duct (qui vient du coup à coté de le thermistance). Comme ça, le ventilateur de la chauffe, tourne toujours (moins de problème de fil qui se coince) et le fan duct est réglable avec repetier.
Si tu as des questions, n'hesite pas à les poser.

Eevee used Shadow Ball. It's super effective!  
This sculpture uses stereographic projection to create a three-tone image of the Pokémon Eevee. Place a light source at the north pole of the sphere, and it will project the undistorted image on the table. The shadow should look correct when printed in natural PLA, although I have not had a chance to test it physically, so you will probably need to experiment with materials and size.

comments.text: I'd be interested to see this printed out, but I'll be very surprised if you get a noticeable difference between the two shades of grey. Light will diffuse out when it hits any thickness of plastic.
comments.author: henryseg

comments.text: Thank you for the interest. I based my thicknesses on the Beer-Lambert law based on a 70% absorption of light in the black areas. However, if the light is primarily diffused rather than absorbed as you say, then Beer-Lambert won't work at all. I guess the only real way to see what will happen is to actually print it out, which I won't be able to attempt for another month.

description.text: The Infinite Clip is our attempt to build a better paperclip using 3D printing. This is the first version and we'd love to have your feedback on how to improve it. The clip works as a hook and can be mounted & clip things in four different orientations. It can clip things in various ways and be used for thick and thin things. Here is our blog post about this thing: http://i.materialise.com/blog/entry/using-3d-printing-to-build-a-better-paperclip-the-infinite-clip

We've tested it on a Stratasys FDM machine and an EOS SLS machine in ABS and polyamide respectively. We tried to make it as flat as possible but it probably won't work on a Makerbot because of support (we didn't try it on ours) but please tell us if it does!

title: Replicator 2 Extruder Upgrade with Adjustable Spring Tension

description.text:
This is a modification of the Replicator 2 Extruder Upgrade by whpthomas, in order to adjust the spring tension as needed. This is probably most beneficial for people who have a hard time finding the right spring for the original design.  
The arm has been modified with a hole for an M4 screw, and cutouts underneath to fit the corresponding nut. There is also a simple plate that fits between the screw and the spring. Note that this plate uses 2mm of the available space for the spring.

I printed with standard PLA and Makerbot Replicator software, high resolution (100 um layer height), 2 shells and 100% infill.  
I rotated the arm to stand upright on what becomes the left sidewall when mounted. On my system, this required about  -88 degrees of rotation around the Y axis, followed by about 5 degrees around the X axis. This will remove the need for printing with supports.  
See the Replicator 2 Extruder Upgrade by whpthomas for extensive instructions on building with ReplicatorG, as well as a bill of materials and assembly instructions.

Enjoy! If you make it... post pics!

"Hum... how about a glass with a compartment for ice cubes in the middle, so the whisky is cooled but not diluted?" What a good idea! Here it is! The compartment is 'angled' so the ice water doesn't run over.

When it's frozen, use it to drink some whisky on the rocks - without diluting your whisky!

author: Paul44

description.text:
Quick and rugged hook to get the snow shovel up off the garage floor.  Holds a steel bladed snow shovel with no problem.  The mounting holes are relieved on the back side so you can use expanding plastic anchors to mount the hook on drywall and still have the hook lay flat against the wall.  
Enjoy!

I printed these parts on a MakerBot 2X in PLA on kapton. Build plate at 70C, extruder at 205C, 3 shells and 15% fill. Print time is about an hour. I turned on supports for the mounting hole relief cuts on the back of the hook. Customizer Settings: Handle_dia: diameter of the handle of the shovel, 33 mm in my case
Mount_height: Vertical height of overall part
Wall: Thickness of the walls of the hook, bigger for more weight
Drop: Amount the hook rakes downward toward the wall
Tab_thickness: Thickness of the plate against the wall
Hole_dia: Diameter of mounting holes
Wedge_height: Vertical height of the hook wedge shape
Fn: Number of facets on cylindrical surfaces
